For a periodic function which is neither even nor odd we can expect at least some of both the \(a_n\) and \(b_n\) to be non-zero. For example consider the square wave function shown in the Figure below:



This function is neither even nor odd and we have already seen in a previous section that its Fourier series contains a constant \( \left(\displaystyle{1}{2} \right) and sine terms.

This result could be expected because we can write \[ f(t) = \dfrac{1}{2} + g(t) \] where \(g(t)\) is as shown:



Clearly \(g(t)\) is odd and will contain only sine terms. The Fourier series are in fact \[ f(t) = \dfrac{1}{2} + \dfrac{2}{\pi} \left( \sin t + \dfrac{1}{3} \sin 3t + \dfrac{1}{5} \sin 5t + \dots \right) \] and \[ g(t) = \dfrac{2}{\pi} \left( \sin t + \dfrac{1}{3} \sin 3t + \dfrac{1}{5} \sin 5t + \dots \right) \]
